comments.commentBody:
Why did the Iraqi army fall apart, and how come our military and intelligence did not know that it was not to be relied upon?

The army fell apart because the men did not trust their officers, who were selected on the basis of patronage, buying political loyalty, and rewarding political loyalty instead of talent. Indeed, talented and intelligent officers would pose a threat to the government, so they were pushed to the side. Maliki assumed that the army would not really have to fight anybody.

We had the same problems building the South Vietnamese army. It did, of course, have to fight, and we were there to rescue it when it did poorly, and do most of the heavy lifting. So we did the fighting and the South Vietnamese government used the army for patronage and regime stability.

We were Uncle Sucker in Vietnam, and some want us to be snookered in Iraq too. Unfortunately, creating a moderate army is going to be very difficult. Such an army threatens Assad more than ISIS. Forced to choose between him and ISIS, most Syrians will choose him. Between him and a believable moderate coalition, the choice will go the other way. So Assad will try to get somebody else to take care of ISIS while he keeps the moderates divided and impotent.

ISIS's ideas come ultimately from Salafism and the Saudis. We need to encourage them to go after Mecca; then and only then will the Saudis fight. And they might well lose, but at least things would for once be clear in the Mideast.

a quibble. Ontario is closer to 40% of the country's population. Ontario has the most seats, but isn't necessarily the decider in elections. Quebec often had that distinction because they often voted overwhelmingly for one party. alberta does too, but its population means it doesn't have as many seats in parliament....

"a country that grew its economy while slashing public spending and debt. Squeezed by high interest rates, a left-of-center government instituted big spending cuts in the 1990s; as a result, Canada’s level of public expenditure as a share of its economy has fallen to match America’s."

The early 1990's and 2008 are completely different. Canada's spending cuts came in a period of general economic expansion and were apparently the result of high interest rates on Canadian Bonds. In addition, they most certainly didn't slash their tax revenue at the same time. Pretty textbook stuff, the economic boom...not the bust...is the time for public fiscal restraint.
The current context is completely different. There has been a global recession/stagnation since 2008. Interest rates are the lowest they have ever been on US bonds. Austerity in a depressed economic environment only will lead to more economic stagnation (And the EU zone is giving everyone a clear case study.)
Finally, if conservatives are so taken by what Canada did in the 1990s, they need only look to the Clinton years. We did the same thing, which resulted in budget surpluses by 2000. At that point, our friends in the Bush administration cut taxes and expanded spending, and in so doing frittered away the benefits of our own "expansionary austerity" of the 1990s.
So, Steve, now it's the "water fast" diet?

Dear Don Wiss,
Good reasoning, but no offense, it seems like you reasoned in order to reach the conclusion you wanted to reach. All the anthropology of paleolithic humans agrees, their life expectancy was about 30 years old (I gave them the benefit of the doubt with 35). Here's a good little informative site on it:

http://anthro.palomar.edu/homo2/mod_homo_5.htm

"...preferably organic. By all standards, that's a good thing."

All fruits and vegetables are organic. Your supermarket does not sell pure titanium, nickel, iron, or silicon.

Show me peer-reviewed evidence that what you consider to be "organic" food is healthier than what you wrongly consider to be "not organic" food.
I predict your prediction will be correct!
Actually, there is a movement to encourage moms to do that. I've read the rationale and I still don't quite get it...
If any mother wants to convince me that she's really on the paleo path, she's going to have to eat her newborn's placenta.

I, on the other hand, have lost 10 lbs and am the fittest I've been in years, and I eat plenty of carbs (love potatoes, bread, rice, dessert, etc.) How did I do this? I have been working out almost every day for the past 3 years (mostly running) and having soup or something lighter for lunch. Couldn't imagine life without carbs!
Well, its environmental impact is not good. Eating a lot of red meat is NOT good for the planet.

"If you want to be fit, slender, and healthy, you have to eat a balanced diet, without extra snacking or useless 'foods' like Doritos, and you have to do some exercise. Sleeping eight hours a night helps."

With the exception of not snacking, these are all parts of the paleo philosophy. Not sure how it's any kind of shortcut, given that transitioning to paleo is quite a lot of work (though like anything, it's easier once you get used to it)--not to mention the widespread ridicule you subject yourself to. One of the bonuses most people find on paleo though, is that we can pretty much eat whenever we want and maintain a slim weight.

People keep switching to paleo and sticking to it because it feels good and makes you healthy, period.
Haha.   You are correct!
like he said — not irish.

Yeah, but don't actual farmers grow grains, which we can then eat in minimally-processed form before the factories get hold of them?  It's the  grain-avoiding part of Paleo that isn't explained by your common-sense philosophy.

OK you New York intellectuals, quit making fun of my paleo friends. I know "caveman" sounds stupid, it is just a marketing name. McDonald is not really Irish food either.

The point is to eat real food, grown by actual farmers and ranchers, or caught by fisherman. Skip the weird processed factory stuff. Do you have a better plan? Cheetos? Coke? That stuff will kill you.

I pity them if they can't see the truth and sheer beauty in Charles' soul. It's rare to have only one of his talents. But all of them put together and having overcome what he did, and so beautifully? One can only hope to achieve a fraction of what Charles has!

You make a valid point about agriculture freeing humans to create art, religion, and literature and other hallmarks of modern civilization. Of course, the cave paintings in Lascaux are estimated to be well over 17,000 years old (pre-dating the commonly accepted rise of agriculture by about 7,000 years), and the creators of these works were almost certainly not growing corn and potatoes and soybeans.

On the other hand, they were French, and probably on strike all the time, so they had ample leisure opportunities to dabble in oil, charcoal, and other mixed media while waiting for the union to come through with a collective hunting agreement.

http://seth-wwwsethsalinger.blogspot.com/2011/10/policy-of-cave-bear.html

The basic argument makes a lot of sense. As a guy who loves to Crossfit, I know a lot of Paleo fanatics.

However, the only reason we can have this discussion is because mankind learned how to farm. Without it, we wouldn't have an Internet to argue about diet advice--we'd be too busy trying to find food. If the whole world went Paleo, there would be horrendous suffering from starvation.
Should they drop athletes with the "wrong" political or religious affiliations?  This is not a good direction in which to go.

Agreed.
We have let our military off the hook how many times? Men and women sit in jail because they decided to expose military crimes, or chose not to fight and go AWOL. But because in that arena, it's NOT domestic violence...and as a soldier you've signed your life away and anyway, it's plain old vanilla violence...that kind of violence is perfectly okay because its war, and the gloves are off...hmmmm, don't ya love our logic?
Should boxing be criminalized? And hockey fighting, they knock their off frequently? Or, because it is 'organized' it is okay!

"Allegations".  Wait until the accused is convicted, if she is convicted.  Anyone can accuse anyone of anything, without evidence.  That's why we have a criminal justice system, with punishment for the guilty and protections for the innocent accused.

These are a lot of widespread myths of hunter-gatherers. Though there was high child mortality, and many people did die young in environmental accidents and war, the lifespan of hunter gatherers, once they made it to adult age, is thought to be not terribly different from today's: http://condensedscience.wordpress.com/2011/06/28/life-expectancy-in-hunt...

In addition, hunter gatherer societies today, anyway, have all kinds of free time, and spend only a few hours a day gathering and hunting food, so not really nasty or brutish: https://libcom.org/history/hunter-gatherers-mythology-market-john-gowdy

(I just looked up the quickest links I could find, but this is widely accepted information in anthropology).

The country's gone nuts.   Hysterical mob rule.  The mob is not in the streets, but in cyberspace.   No rational dialogue, just "how badly can we punish these people"?   Everyone afraid not to be "tough", for fear of being accused of not caring about domestic violence.   No discussion of proportionality of punishment.    Professional talking heads afraid to dissent, to put their jobs on the line.

Ahh,  nothing like getting out at dawn and herding a few elk off a cliff!  Eat up those guts as they spill out of the belly and are still steaming.  I skin one or two with a bone knife and my wife chews the hides to soften the leather.  All that chewing has ruined her teeth till she ain't much to look at so while she drags the carcasses back to the cave I have a little fun with her younger sister.
Yes, and one's conscience.
I agree that children don't realize where their food comes from and they should.  Let's take them to  slaughter houses to see what their parents are feeding them.

Has the media gone loco? Do you see the headline? - allowed to play while accused? Stop it. Just stop it. These are businesses just like the grocery store and the nail polishing industry. You think grocery clerks and nail polishers never hit their families? Do you think they will do it more if Hope Solo gets to play soccer? People sometimes do bad things to each other. There's probably less striking of children and women in America than at any time in our history. We just have a much more ubiquitous media that has found a sexy issue to rant on about.

What do you want to happen to these families? Do you want to destroy their lives by taking away the biggest salary in the family? Do you want NFL wives to keep silent if they are hit so that their husbands don't lose their jobs? How do we know what happened? Must everything be black and white politically correct witch hunting?

For crying out loud - people do not approve of domestic violence but Commissioner Goodell sounded the other day like he was apologizing for hitting his own wife. Enough already.

Not everybody agrees with this witch hunting. It's the media which love scandal and the businesses which are terrified of probably non-existent or ineffective boycotting.

Playing while accused - for crying out loud. Enough already.
Before the present rash of sick sports stories is over, people are gonna be longing for the good old days of Donald Sterling who never did anything but say bad things about other people.
